div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.

THE DANGER. The South African War showed only too clearly the military weakness of the British Empire when pitted against an antagonist of the third class. Had the Boers pressed their initial advantages, had they been under the guidance of leaders like Botha or Delarey from the ouset, even this enemy might have withstood the forces of the Empire. Trained men were lacking at the outset, and though the courage of the British soldier and the patriotism of the mother country and the Colonies enabled os to wear down oar adver saries at immense expense in a three years' war, it is e strange commentary on the military ignorance of the English people that they regarded a victory won under such circum stances by the greatest colonial Power as some- thing highly creditable to themselves. Had the nation possessed any appreciation of what war really involves, had it devoted to military preparation a tenth of the time devoted to sport and amusement, it would have seen the Boer war finished within a twelve month. Bat, when a few years of preparation would have sufficed to make victory not only over the burgher levies but over far more dangerous foes a certainty, the English people pre ferred to muddle through. Close on four years have elapsed since the war ended but oar army, in the opinion of experts, is no better fitted for a life-and-death struggle. Our publicists assume too hastily that we shall never be involved in a land campaign against a great European Power. In the political world of to-day new groupings and alliances of the Powers take place with a curious frequency. Ten years ago we were no: on good terms with France or the United States, while our relations with Germany were excellent. Since then the Entente Cordiale with France has been feted and celebrated.'Germany is our “bete noire;" but who is to guarantee that the present alliances and understandings are permanent! For that reason, if for no other, we must prepare ourselves for a straggle in which we may stand alone, remembering above all that under present military conditions a struggle with England cannot be a life-and- death battle for any of our possible opponents. War with England is war with limited liability for oar opponents. Oar fleet may injure his commerce and sink his ships if it can reach them in their fortified harbours but it cannot seize their capitals or overrun their provinces, while success on their part will mean our ruin, and even at the close of an indecisive war we
may well find that our enemy and we ourselves have been playing the game of an ambition neutral who has attained pride of place among the Powers through our exhaustion. It may be urged against compulsory service or compulsory military training — though the names differ the -principle is the saine—that the danger to the Empire of a struggle in the future against a well-trained and equipped opponent or coalition oi opponents is proble- matical: why prepare for a combat that may never take place ! Bat why do business houses insure their-offices against tire- and burglary! The principle is. the same: the chances of the ere not perhaps great in the case of a bank or a business, but a practical man must take, them into consideration. Are the real rulers of the Empire, the British electorate, unaware that to them overthrow in war means universal ruin, and that they are called upon to insure themselves, not against the blind forces of nature and hazard, but against the keen in- telligence and organised resources of their many rivals,’ who even at the present moment we know to be using every effort to prepare themselves so as to be thoroughly ready to overthrow the British Empire? No Briton can believe that the British race has grown so supine and careless of its great past and future, that, when the question of universal training I without any assumptions whatever is properly and squarely laced before the citizens of the British Empire, they, the citizens of the greatest Empire that the world has ever seen, will not at once of their own tree will volun- tarily take up the sacred burden of preparing themselves for the defence of the British Empire. But they forget that our understanding with France and oar alliance with Japan make it necessary for us to give military as well as naval support to our allies. Had the Morocco imbroglio ended in a European conflict, could we have given direct military aid to the French Republic Be it remembered that the German Army, though it has its weaknesses, is stronger in numbers, and has the brain and manhood of the German nation in its ranks, is less diviced by religions and political dissensions, and is better served by a huge and complex railway. system than that of its opponen s, that Russia is out of action for the present, and that Austria, which could not gain from a German defeat and is bound by treaty to assist her ally, is not ah enemy to be despised and could support Germany with a powerful and well organised army. The forces of the Re- public may lose their fi at pitched battle; could we then have confined ourselves to the blockade of the German coasts or to attacks on Hamburg-Amerika liners ? Bat during the Moroccan crisis we were impotent to aid France by land. The 100,000 men who were to seise the Kiel Canal did dot exist save on paper at the moment that was most threaten- ing, and though they bight have bean collect ed and organised in a couple of months the po-sibility of a surprise would have been lost and the issue of the campaign might have been decided against the Republic between Metz and Chalons-sur-Marne. Russia is out of action at present. Tree, bat who knows what may emerge from the welter of bloodshed and confusion in which the great Northern Empire is plunged l The French Revolution produced Napoleon, and the Russian people may yet go forth conquer- ing and to conquer under the banner of some Saviour of Society. And whatever the up- shot of the straggle that Russia has now to face, her foreign and military policy, mart remain unchanged.- The policy of a great land-locked empire mast aim in the future at reaching the open water as it has aimed in the past, and Russian statesmen said soldiers will, take the line of least resistance when the next movement comes. The Port Arthur gate is dosed, there remain the gates of the Baltic, the Dardanelles, Alexandretta,and the Persian Gulf. In the Baltic Russia will have to grapple with Germany and the small but vigorous and patriotic Scandinavian States, in the Dardanelles she mast face Austria,. Turkey, and the Balkan States, who will feel that their aspirations are doomed if once the great Slav nation wins the key to the Mediterranean. At Alexandretta the Russians may have to face the world of Islam fighting with the consciousness that defeat means otter rain, and, it may well be, aided by the German Empire. Persia remains, and over the shores of the Persian Gulf we have proclaimed a new Monroe doctrine, but can we support our political thesis by armed action should our virtual protectorate be challenged ? Our dig- nity and prestige forbid us to rely entirely on Japanese aid, and can we be certain that the alliance will be in force in fifteen or twenty years’ time?

Sanitary Dept. Drs. Antoine E Gonatas, Assimakis P. Assi- macopoulo, and Anastase M. Tsamados, M. Dib G. Vitale, pharmacist; and M. Abdel Hamid Ezzat, veterinary surgeon, have been authorised to practise in Egypt.

Small Dance. We may remind our Alexandria readers of the small dated to be given at.the New Khe- divial Hotel this evening, on the occasion of the Orthodox New Year’s Eve. Dancing will commence at 10 p m.

Embezzlement. One of Messrs. Thos. Cook and Son’s em- ployes was brought up before, the Cairo Con- sular “Court to-day on a charge- of embezzling the sum of L E. 257. The case was still being heard at the time our correspondent tele- phoned.

Rifle Meeting. The programme of the Army and Navy Rifle Meeting, which is to be held on the Abbassieh rifle ranges on tje 12th, 13th, 14th, and 45th February, has been issued. There are 26 competitions on the programme, which contains all the regulations for the meeting.

The Garrison Church. On Sunday next the Rev Harry G. Rorison, M. A., R N., H. M. S. Minerva, will preach in H. B. M.’s Garrison Church of St. George, Mustspha Pacha, at the 11 o’clock parade service. Full Choral matins, baud and choir of the 1st Royal Dublin Fusiliers supplemented by the new organ. Visitors will be welcomed.

Good Bargains. Visitors and residents who wish to obtain real bargains in Carpets, Brassware, Lamps, Moushrabeah, Embroideries, and Silks- should go to Maliuk’s, Rond Point Mouski, Cairo, where the whole stock' is to be sold regardless, of cost, as the proprietor is retiring from business. Everything will be sold; so do not lose the opportunity.’ No reasonable offer will be refused. 1906. We continue to receive artistic and useful calendars and other advertising notions for the year 1906. The Eastern Telegraph Company is distributing a very handy pocket diary, as also is Mr. Nestor Gianaclis, the cigarette manufacturer,and the Standard Life Assurance Co. The latter company is also sending out an excellent blotter. One of the most effective almanacks is that issued by the Manufacturers Life Insurance Company of Toronto, Canada, which consists of an excellent commercial and strategic map of the British Empire.
NOTES FROM PORT SAID. (From our Correspondent). Port Said Friday.

A Record Pilgrimage. Judging from the number of pilgrims going to the Hedjaz, this year’s exodus to Mecca’ promises to put up a record. The rumours-that many of the pilgrims were arguing is another of the many rumours evidently caused by the publicity given to the little affair at Alex andria. Similar roumors of the secret im- portation of arms into Beyrout and other places are common, and seem to be alike groundless. That there is unrest-among some of the natives is acknowledged. But equally one might say that at present half the world seems in the throes of political changes. Whether this is due to the appearance of sun spots or some other meteorological phono mena, as his lately been suggested, is not for us to say. However, as far as Egypt is con- cerned, there is practically no cause for the anxiety which seems, according to some of our papers, to be felt.

Popularity of German Steamers. The North German Lloyd and other Ger- man lines seem to have gained considerable popularity of late, judging from the number of passengers who now patronize their boats. Australians especially seem to appreciate the accommodation and reduced fares The Massa- geries Line also is Well supported and the giving of fourth-class passages seems to be popular with the poorer travellers.. The other classes are all well supported. But the English lines, in spite-of competition, still more than hold their own. However, it has been noticed that Germany. is making a big bid for trade to the East. The recent articles in the English press 'Advocating more attention to this competition, especially with Australia, and South and East Africa, are well worthy of consideration, though possibly a little coloured by rabid imperialistic writers to a press always ready to catch at such information.

POLITICAL ATMOSPHERE. REPORTED TO BE CLEARING. effect on stock markets. (Gazette's Special Service.) London, Saturday, Jan. 13. The clearing political atmosphere is produc ing a complete change in the stock marke's, which seem to be returning to the same healthy activity as prevailed before the war.

DEATH OF SIR MOUNTSTUART GRANT DUFF. London January 12. | The Right Honourable Sir Mountstuart; Elphinstone Grant Duff, G.C.S.I., is dead. (Reuter) The news of Sir Mountstuart Grant Duff’s death will be received with sorrow by a very wide circle of readers, for his “Notes from a Diary" placed him in the front rank of me- moir writers ; in fact, with the exception of Sir Horace Rumbold, whose “Recollections” and “Further Recollections” will hold a place with “Notes from a Diary," memoir writers are now an extinct race. Sir Mountstuart thus he'd an almost unique position amongst Eng- lishmen of the-present generation. He alone among English politicians made a systematic and thorough study of the internal politics of European countries. Englishmen, as a rule, know, little of the problems which perplex other nations, and care eve i less. Sir M. Grant Duff was, however,a brilliant exception. He had an immense circle of acquaintances- scattered all over Europe, in all classes of society. One can hardly mention an eminent man or woman, during the last half century who was not personally known to Sir M. Grant Duff. This gave him a great ad van- tage in dealing with foreign-affairs. As Sir Robert Morier once said, “He avoids all the besetting sins of the usual British writers on foreign subjects, nagging, school-master- ing, patronising, and the taking of some ri- diculous, imaginary British standard as that by which to measure un-British things.” The “Notes from a dairy,” which were publish ed in a number of instalments ’ from 1897 to 1904, are charming reading. They are a kind of human personal link with a generation which is rapidly passing away. Sir M. Grant Doff was a diligent diarist, having noted down each day's events ever since his eighteenth birthday. After having kept a diary for a quarter of a century, he re-read what he had written, and came to the conclusion that there was much which possessed permanent interest. He accor- dingly made copious extracts which he publish- ed in the “Notes,” .and which will be as 'indispensable to the student of the social history of England in the latter half as Greville’s is of the earlier period of the nineteenth century.

ARMY OF OCCUPATION. Major G. C. Knight, Loyal North Lancashire Regiment, bas been transferred from the ap- pointment of Deputy Assistant Adjutant General, Malta, to the appointment of Deputy Assistant Adjutant and Quarter Master Gene- ral at Cairo. He arrived in Egypt on Thursday, and- has been taken on the strength of the command from that dater-inclusive. . Major A. H. C. Kenney-Herbert.D.A.Q.M.G., will carry out the duties of Major, General Staff, until the termination of his appointment in Egypt. The General Officer Commanding will carry out the annual inspection of the undermention- ed units on the dates stated :— 2nd Co., R.G.A , Citadel, Monday, 15th January ; Mili- tary Mounted Police, Abbassieh, Tuesday, 16th January; 2nd Bn. Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, Kasrel Nil, Wednesday, 7th January.

THE PROCES DES PRINCES. The"proces des Princes” will be heard before the Cairo Mixed Tribunal on the 15th inst. M Poincare is on his way from Paris to plead and considerable interest is being taken in the Case.

MENA HOUSE. The small dance given by the management of Mena House Hotel will take place on the 24th February, instead of the 17th, as pre- viously stated. The special moonlight service organised by the Cairo. Tramway Company during the week brought a crowd of people out to the Pyramids every night, and donkey and camel riding was in great favour. Mena House Hotel was well patronized on these nights. Tourists as well as residents gave dinner parties there and strolled out afterwards into the pleasant grounds of the hotel to enjoy the exceptionally bright moon. A concert will be given at Mena House Hotel tomorrow by the Bracale orchestra. The programme during luncheon is as follows : March-Fun of the Fair—Lincke. Overture—Semiramis-Rossini. Fantaise-Samson and Dalila-Saint Saens. Chanson di Printemps-Mendelssohn. Capricieuse—Gillet. Following is the programme in the afternoon for the concert on the large terrace : Marche-Einzug der Gladiatoron—Jueik. Valse—La Housarde—Ganne. Overture- Poet et Paysan -Suppe, Fantaisie- Cavalleria Rusticana-Mascagni. Suite Espagnole—-La Feria—Lacombe. Danza delle ore—Gioconda—Ponchinelli,

DOCTOR’s FEES LAST NIGHT’S MEETING. DELEGATES TO DOCTORS SELECTED, It is generally considered that the official reply of the members of the Alexandria Medi- cal Association is regard to the criticisms that have been-passed on their recent decision - to increase their fees, is merely, an attempt to throw cost in the eyes of the public. They vaunt their gratuitous, or partially gratuitous, work in the hospitals, but of course they omit to mention, how eager they are to obtain such employment as an advertisement. Much comment has been aroused as to the anonymity of the medical men who belong to this ‘Ordre des Medecins.” HaVe they presi- dent or chairman, or at any rate somebody whose not afraid to sing his, name. A largely attended meeting was held yester- day at the headquarters of the Risorgimento” Society. A large number of representatives of various societies, association's, Masonic lodges, etc., put in ah appearance. After some dis- cussion it was unanimously decided that the reply of the Alexandria. Medical Association, as published in the local Press, could not be considered satisfactory to the inhabitants of Alexandria. The meeting nominated seven delegates who will represent a large number of benevolent societies, Masonic lodges, artisans’ corporations, and other bodies, to interview the Alexandria Medical Association and to demand an explanation, so that the question of the doctors’ fees man be placed on a satisfactory basis in order to avoid any future misunder- standing between the population and the mem- bers of the medical profession. It was also decided that in case the Alexan- dria Medical Association failed to give satis- faotory assurances the Egyptian Government and the Alexandria Municipality should be approached on the matter so as to intervene on behalf of the people of Alexandria. The meeting ended at about 11 p.m.

DEPARTURE OF THE MAHMAL. Ibrahim Fathi Pacha, the Emir el Hag, and the other officials connected with the pilgrimage left Abbassieh this morning with the Mahmal by special train for Suez. They will proceed to the Hedjaz on board the S.S. Rahmanieh. The pilgrims who are to accompany the Mahmal will leave on board the S.S. Mariout, sailing from Suez to-morrow afternoon.

THE JUDICIAL COMMISSION. Yesterday the International Judicial Com- mission held its sitting at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. All the delegates, except Judges Batcheller and Larcher, were present. Lord Cromer also attended. The first question discussed was as to the proportion of foreigners in a jury in the case of prosecution against foreigners or natives. It was decided that the proportion of each should be equal. The question' of the "concordat preventif” was then debated and the matter was left to the Sub-Commission. A question of the conflict of jurisdiction between the three Mixed Courts in the case of appeal from summary judgments was raised by Count A. de Zogheb. the Danish delegate, but was ruled not in order by Boutros Pasha Ghali. Lord Cromer, the first British delegate, then claimed for the Government the right of, initiative in presenting projects. The expropriation project was agreed to without discussion. The Sub Commission will meet at Alexandria next month.

ALEXANDRIA’S ROADS. The Sub committee of the Alexandria Mu- nicipal Delegation will hold a meeting this afternoon in order to consider the programme of the roads which are to be made this year in Alexandria and Ramleh. We understand that the transverse roads be ween rue Rosette and rue d’Allemagne will form a prominent part of this programme, as a large amount of- building has boon taking place in this quarter. At the same time it cannot be expected that roads will be made in those streets where buildings still going on, as if that were done the roads would be spoilt as soon as they ware made.

FIGHT IN THE DESERT. A body of guards belonging to the Repression of the Slave Trade Department lately marched for several days into the desert, near Assouan,with the object of capturing Mohamed El Faradjawi, who had been sentenced in default to three years’ imprisonment for kid- napping a Sudanese woman of Aklelt, in the Assouan moudirieh. Having got wind of the soldiers’ object, and fearing that they would kill Mohamed, his brother gathered together a large number of Bedouins of the neighbourhood, many of whom used to be interested in the slave trade between Egypt and the Hedjuz, and started out to Support Mohamed. The two parties met in the desert and a fight ensued between them. The Bedouins began the firing and the soldiers, retaliated. One of the guards was wounded but the Bedouins were soon defeated and fled, carrying off some of their wounded. They left behind them some camels, a Remington, four swords, and a quan- tity of cartridges and provisions.

RACING IN CAIRO. SKYE MEETING. BIG ATTENDANCE AND GOOD RACING. Yesterday's Skye Meeting at the K. S. C. grounds came off in capital weather. The attendance was first-rate, residents and visitors crowding the enclosure and the grandstand and the racing was extremely good, 'some splendid finishes taking place. In, the fourth race Soudfi just got home by less than a head from Sinounou while in the fifth' there was a desperate struggle between Mikado and Boule de Neige, Mr. Sursock’s little grey, cleverly ridden by Mr. Michaelides, drawing dead level at the post after being apparently beaten by Mikado. The third race was also good, Ameer being only beaten by a head. Two horses ran rather disappointingly- Suheil, which had a lot of support in the second race, and El Tahawi which was well backed in both the second and the fifth, but completely failed in both. A. S. C. — We are asked by the clerk of the coarse to give notice that the race course will be open for trial gallops on Wednesday morning next, the 17th inst., from six to ten.

STEAMER MOVEMENTS — The SS Spartan Prince with passengers and general cargo, left Manchester on Thurs- day, and is due at Alexandria, via Tunisand Malta, on or about 26th inst. The Canard S.S. Veria arrived at Liverpool on Wednesday morning.
PERSONAL AND SOCIAL

H. R. H. Prince Charles William of Sweden is expected to return to Alexandria from his trip Upper Egypt afternoon of the 91st inst;., and will attend a dinner to be given that evening by Mr. C. Belifante Osthberg, Swedish Consul-General, on the occasion of the birthday of the King of Sweden. The following day his Royal Highness, as well as the officers of the Swedish corvette Freja will be entertained to tea i i the afternoon at the New Khedi- vial. Hotel by H. E the Governor of Alexan- dria and to dinner in the evening. The Prince will leave with the Freja for Constantinople on the 23rd inst.
The Hon. Eve’yn Baring has maintained the improvement noted yesterday.

Sig. Ojetti, the well-known Italian journalist, is on a visit to Cairo with his charming young wife. Sig. Ojetti is one of the principal contri- butors to our brilliant contemporary, the "Coirriere de la Sera,” and has had a long connection with all the chief Italian reviews, Dr. and Mrs. Bentley entertained a large party at dinner at the Tewfik Palace Hotel to celebrate the coming of age of their pretty daughter Eileen. An Italian string band played during and after dinner for the small dance, which was kept up until it was time to catch the last train to Cairo.

The members of the Societe des Medecins Hellenes d’Alexandrie are giving a dinner at the New Khedivial Hotel on Wednesday, next in honour of Dr. Kartoulis, physician to the Government Hospital, on the occasion of his appointment to the honorary professorship of the Berlin Faculty of Medicine. The Greek Consul-General will preside.

ACCIDENT to steamer in canal (From our Correspondent). Suez, Friday. Last Wednesday evening the homeward- bound steamer Balmoral struck the side of the canal near 146 station and broke her stem-, post in consequence of which traffic in, the canal that night was stopped for several hours until the vessel was moored. Next morning the the Titan was sent to her assistance and towed her into the Bitter Lakes so as to torn her round and bring her to Suez for repairs, where she arrived this after- noon.

PLAGUE ON SHIP.
(Prom our Correspondent). Suez, Friday. On board the homeward-bound B. I. steamer Itria, from Calcutta, a case of plague was discovered by the Quarantine medical officer, and landed in the phi p’s boat and conveyed to Moses’ Wells for treatment. The vessel, after being thoroughly disinfected, was allowed to proceed on her voyage through the canal in stiet quarantine.

RED SEA LIGHTHOUSES. Count de Vaureal and the Countess de Vaureal are now staying in Cairo. Count de Vanreal, who is the Director of the Ottoman h I Ports and Lights Administration, leaves next week for Aden, whence he will start on a tour of inspection in the Red Sea which will last till the end of February.

TO-DAY’S TELEGRAMS.

ELECTION CAMPAIGN. ROWDYISM RAMPANT. CANDIDATES PELTED WITH MUD. •London, January 12 A more sober tone is manifest in press controversies on the eve of the election, but rowdyism is as rampant as ever. Some candi- dates have been pelted with mud and stones. Mr. Lloyd George at Leamington and Mr. Lyttelton, at ,Warwick were shouted down. Speaking at Perth, Mr. Asquith warned the country that a reduction of taxation is impossible till the general level of expenditure be reduced and provision be made for the redemption of the National Debt. (Feuter)

ELECTION RETURNS London, January 12. Sir C. Furness has been elected unopposed for Hartlepool. Mr. F. W. [Chance, Radical, Carlisle, Mr. Taylor, U., Liverpool, and Mr. B. Jones, Radical, Swansea, have been returned unop- posed. (Reuter)

STATE OF RUSSIA. PACIFICATION OF BAlTIC -PROVINCES. St. Petersburg, January 12 The pacification of the Baltic provinces is proceeding steadily. An official despatch states that two bombs were thrown from an Armenian seminary at Tiflis into a Cossack patrol, wounding four and killing a boy. The house was surrounded and bombarded. A store of bombs exploded and killed 33 persons, besides wounding 300. Another house from which bombs had been thrown was similarly bombarded and an ex- plosion took place by which eight insurgents were killed. (Reuter)>

FRENCH LOAN TO RUSSIA. Paris, January 12. The 'Temps’ states that the French banks have decided to advance Russia 266,000,000 francs at 5 1/2%. This will not involve an export of gold, as the capital will remain in the banks against Russian drafts. (Reuter)

AMERICAN COTTON CROP. ACTION OF COTTON GROWERS. London, January 12. The Southern Cotton Growers Association has met at New York to consider the advi- sability of holding the balance of the crop until 15 cents per pound can be obtained, and or sending a Commission to China and the East to find new fields for the surplus production. It is announced that there will be a con- ference of spinners on the 24th instant to arrange an understanding. (Reuter)

THE FRENCH PRESIDENCY. Paris, January 12. The Presidential election is fixed for the 17th instant. (Reuter) Paris, January 12. The election of the President of the Republic has been definitely fixed to take place on the 17th inst. M. Rouvier has officially stated that he is not a candidate. M. Failures on taking over the presidency recalled the work of the Senate and his desire to better the condition df the workmen. (H.)

EGYPT’S PROSPERITY. In referring to the Egyptian Budget for the current year, the "Manchester Courier” com- ments as follows on the increasing prosperity of the country: The splendid results due to the intervention of Great Britain in Egypt are again exemplified in the comments on the Budget of that country for 1906 made by Sir Vincent Corbett, Finan- cial Adviser to the Khediva’s Government. No longer robbed and cheated out of their earnings the fellaheen are becoming not merely content- ed but prosperous. One result of the "sadden Requisition of unexpected wealth” by large sections of the people is the almost inevitable economic result of higher prices for necessaries. The income of Egypt continues to increase, though remissions of taxation to the extent of nearly half a-million sterling have been made in the past three years; and for next year, despite the growing cost of unskilled labour on public works, the surplus is again estimated at about half a million. One result of this pros- perity is the invasion of the speculator, and Sir Vincent cautions investors against the gambling fever and wild cat schemes to be found in Egypt. Unfortunately for the cotton crop, while the area under cultivation has considerably increased the quantity raised has remained stationary. Apparently the high prices ruling have tempted growers to take too much out of the soil, cotton now being grown on the same land every two years instead of once in three years. Money from outside Egypt continues to be poured into it in pursuance of mining developments and exploration, but it is to early yet to test the value of this finan- cial enterprise. Thanks to the large reserve fund possessed by the Government and the less stringent restrictions now imposed on it by foreign bondholders, the railways of the country are being increased and improved, while ano- ther barrage on the Nile has been arranged for, which will place other two hundred and forty square miles of fertile country under cultivation. Sir Vincent’s report will strengthen the con- fidence of both Great Britain and Egypt in the ability and resourcefulness of the great Pro- Consul Lord Cromer.

OUR SUDAN Letter from Sir Rudolf von Slatin. Dear Mr. Ward,—Your delightful and most interesting book on the Sudan has reached me. I congratulate you heartily on the excellent manner in which the work is written and illustrated. All of us who have done our little best to regenerate the country, after its terrible misfortunes, have received more than kind treatment at your hands. I don't suppose anyone realises more than I do the change that has come over the Sudan since my old and tyrannical master the Khalifa disappeared from the scene. Your description of the Peace and Progress is in fact, a sequel to my 'Fire and Sword in the Sudan.’ With Kindest regards, believe me, yours sincerely, Rudolf V Slatin.

CHRONIQUE FINANCIERE Alexandrie, 12 janvier. An point de vue financier l’annee 1906 se présenté sous nil tout autre aspect que l’annee 1905. Tandis que- celle-ci a débuté par one marche ascensionnelle rapide que n’out pu arreter ni les emissions de nombreuses sociétés nouvelles les desastres russes de Mandchou- rie, celle la commence sous des auspices pins sombres soit comma politique, -soit comme situation generale du marche Sans doute les nouvelles venues de Rus ont été exagerees, l’etat da tesor russe est satisfaisant et le calme semble être définitivement retabli dans l’empire des Tzars, mais ne fautil compter poor rien le decouragement et la crainte qui accom- pagnent les grandes crises ? Sans doute aussi les affaires du Maroc, comma d’ailleura nous l’avons indique dans notre dernière chroniqne, prennent une meil- leure tournure, grace a une detente entre les gouvernemeuts de Londres et de Berlin et aux proteatati- ns pacifiqnea de Guillanme, mais il n’en eat pas moins 'vrai qne Je monde de la speculation ne sera complètement rassuré que lejour ou la conference d’Algesiras aura (indistinguishable) les droits de chacun et que les puissances (indistinguishable) ressees auront conforme leurs actes aux deci sions de cette conference. Si maintenant du terrain polbique on so transports sur le marche mo’ d’aire, on trouve e encore des points noirs ft L’horizon :'bien que le taux d’escompte, en Angleterre, ait reussi a se maintenir an niveau anterieur ce taux a baisser d’un huitime, malgre ana exportation d’or considerable en Amerique. ce taux fluc- tad en Allemagne autor de 8%, moins, il est vrai, pour cause politique que par suite de l’-activite commercials qui absorbe toute le disponibilites: il faut savoir, en (indistinguishable) que l’Allemagne a double en 25 ans son comme-co exterieur qui atteint ft l’heure actuelle le chip fre de 12 milliards de marks; sa marine mar- ehande a passe dans ces 10 dernieres annees de 27 a 42 millions de tonnes. Quant a la Banque de France, ses sorties d'or depaesent de bean- coup ses rentrees, et comme elle a dejad emis pour 4905 millions de billets sur les 5 milliards qu’elle a le droit d’emettre, on se demande comment elle sortira d’embarras, si la situation actuelle se prolonge. Ce coup d’oeil jete sur l’etat financier gene- ral, qu’on nous permette de faire observer que- ai les bourses europeennes ne sont pas encore fibres de to, les inquietes, les diffi- cultes les pins graves out deja ete surmontées et que l’horizin politique seat en peu éclairci Enfin, ainsi que nous le disions vendredi passe, l’Egypte ne recevta, au pis aller, qu’un choc attenue, teinpere en la circonstance par la prospdrite croissante du pays an point de van agricole, commercial et meme industrial. Apres une ouvertare assez ferme samedi, nous avons fléchi sous l’influence des mah- vaises nouvelles politiques, mois ensuite ces nouvelles s’etant ameliorees nous n’avons pas tarde a reprendre Lundi, date de l’anniversaire de l'avenement au trône de S.A. le Khedive, notre Bourse a été farmee. Entre temps les marches europeans etant venus en baisse, notre cote en general a reactionne, a l’exception de qeulques valeurs qui out continue a monter. mais les transactions sont restees a peu près nulles sur 'tonte ft ligue. Le jour suivant mer credi, notre place a montre de soutien et meme de l'animation, en depit de la baisse ft Londres. Les Trams, les Estates et l’Agricole out été particulierement recherches. Hier, sans motif feen apparent, une reaction s’est produites, ex- capte toutefois sur les valuers foncieres : Trust, Building,' Comptoir et Urbaine. Aujourd’hui enfin, nous clôturons en plein marasme. L semaine peut donc se resumer dans ces deux mots : baisse et inaction a peu pres saillants Parmi les événements. les plus saillants de ces derniers jours il fant signaler la fusion de l’Anglo-American Nile avec la Hamburg Ame- rica Linie. Cette decision a revu 3/16 de cours a l’Anglo-Amorican qui a revu ainsi le conrs de 5 7/8, mais en cloture en revient a 5/13/16 La Society Eaux du Cairo a jnaugure dernierement son exploitation de la ligue Zeitoun Matarieh qui promet de beaux bene faces. On parle d’un coupon 10 francs. L’Improvements Corporation a venda a Choubrah un lot d 32 feddans de terrains a batir daus lequel elle a une quotepart do 1/5 Le benefice resultant pour elle de cette vente est da 2800 litres. Vendue elgament la propriété connue sous le nom de “Batigelli Villas.” Les Estates
l’avaient achete récemment; ils l’ont revendu avec un joli benefice, a 14 livres lo mètre. Arrivons maintenant aux on-dit: la Daira ne dounerait pas moins de £20, mais la liqui- dation n’aurait lien qu’empressa la revente du paquet d’action Credit Foncier que la Soeiete possède. Les Investments donneraient un divi- dende de 10 %, ,ce qui. sur un quart du capital versé, ne ferait en définitive que 2 1/2 pour cent. On parle d’une emission de 24,000 ac- tions nouvelles Egyptian Enterprise and Deve- lopment, dont 16 000 seraient reserves aux anciens porteurs. On avait aussi annonce pour janvier une émission d’actions nouvelles Ur- baines et Rurales : et voilà qu’a ce bruit vie de s’ajouter celui de la fu-ion de. cette Société avec les Building Lauds. Pour finir, enfin, on attribue la hausse du Comptoir Financier et Commercial h la decision do distribuer an dividende provisoire. Lw conflit existant entre la Corporation des agents do change do Cairo et la haute finance de la capitale s’est aggrave : en effet, l’assem blee générale des courtiers, tenue avant hie- soir, a approuve par 32 voix coicontre 4 et 3 abstentions l’achat du terrain Sabet pour la construction de la Bourse. Cette decision rend l’entente entre les deux parties beaucoup plus difficile. Nous ne pouvons dore cette chronique sans signaler les principales fluctuations qui se sont produites sur notre marche Banque Natio- nale a perdu 5/16 a 25 9/16. la Delta Light 7/16 a 11 1/2, la Behera 1/2 a 35 la cassa di Seonto 7 francs a 207 3/4 la Deferred Delta 1 /2 a 12 1/2, les Sinceres 5 francs a 6. En revanche, la Dividende Tramways d’Ale xandrie a gagne 30, francs ft 322, la Dividende Crown Brewery 11 francs a 124, et le Comptoir Financier et Commercial 9/32 ft 4 5/8. Mais l’ensemble des fluctuations indique une baisse sensible et presque generale, comme on peut s’en rendre compte par le tableau ci- esdsus. Notre conclusion n’a pas besoin d’etre expo- se. Elle est deja mise en pratique par la spe- culation eclaires’, qui se désintérasse momenta- nement des valeurs- trop assunjetties aux caprices des marches europeens,jusqu’a ce que la situation politique et monétaire se soit bien eclaircie, poor se rejeter sur les valeurs depen dant presque uniquement de la prosperite locale, c’est-a-dire les valeurs foncières egyp tiennes.

REVUE COMMERCIALE Coton Pour ne pas déroger autecedents, la seance de Samedi matin a été Calme, plutot faible et a fini en perte de. 1/32 a 1/16 sur les cours de la veille, mais au moins cette fois la tenue du marche n’etait que naturelle, apres la cloture d’Amerique arrivee avec’une dizaine de points de baisse et avec la nouvelle qua la National Ginners Association venait de pu- blier son rapport indiquant Balles 9,646,000 comique égrenées au ler Janvier. Avec un pareil chiffre, confirmant pour ainsi dire les pronostics a propos da Census Bureau attendu pour Lundi, on ;devait logiquement prévoir une continuation de la baisse pour le lendemain: il en a été ainsi, d’ailleurs, car New York eat venu dimanche matin avec- 20 ' points de baisse, mais la chance des haussiers ayant voulu que lundi fut un jour férié chez nous, a l’occasion de la Noel Orthodoxe, cette suspension d’affaires leur évita une mauvaise journee tout en leur permettant d’attendre les evenements. A la réouverture du marché mardi matin, l’annuonce que la publication du Rapport du Census Bureau était renvoyée de 24 heures et la petite reprise de 5 points qui l’accompagnait Grant naitre un peu d’espoir et comme consé quence, les deux seances de fa journée reste rent calme, avec une perte de 1/32 le matin, vite regagnée dans l’après-midi, ce qui nous, ramena an niveau de samedi, de tacon que, pratiquement, les 25 points perdus par l’Ame riqne dans cet intervalle. sont passés comma quaintite négligeable et sans produire le moin- ‘ dre effet sur nous. Mercredi matin, les dépêches de New-York nous servirent simultanément et le rapport du Census Bureau donnant balles 9.722.000, chif- fre conforme aux previsions, et l’avis, que grace aux efforts inouïs des haussiers, le marche, avait fini en amelioration de 5 points, chose qui etait absolument inattendue ! Quoi qu’il on soit, l’effet de ces deux nouvelles si contra- dictoires outre elles se traduisit par an pen do calme dans la matinée ; mais, dans la soirée, le Commerce a’exportation ayant fait quelques achats en contrats Janvier surtout, et le Caire ft ce que l'on dit, ayant largement opéré dans le sens de la hausse, un revirement complet ent lieu sur notre marché et la finale, quoiqu’a- près one certaine réaction, se résuma en une hausse 3/16 a 1/4 de tallari. Hier, malgre la baisse de l’Amerique et malgré les dépêches disant que Neill mainte- nait son estimation de 11 1/2 millions de balles, la fermeté de notre marche s’est ac- entende et le resultat de la journée a con siste eu une avance de 7/32; mais le comble de la surprise a été atteint aujord’hui quand, en dépit de tout et de tons, le parti de la hausse ici et an Cairo a cru devoir pousser lea prix. Pour on .moment, le cours de 15 19/32 a été pratique, mais ceci a été le maximum, la cloture de la journee ayant fini par avoir lien sur la cote de 15 1/2 De vendredi a vendredi, nous avons don gague près de 9/32, ce qui semble inouï si l’on considère que de l’autre cote de l’Atlan- tique lea choses ont marche tout autrement, le resume du mouvement la-bas montrant une perte nette de 28 a 30 points.—Dans tous les cas, on ne dira pas, pour ce qui nous concerne, que la samaine n’a pas été interessante sous le rapport des, fluctuations et de l’allure du marche; quant a l’activite, qnoiqu’ele n’ait été qu’intermittente, dans L’ensemble, pourtant, elle a été relativement satisfaisante. La nouvelle récolte, tout en etant ferme, est restée presque en dehors da mouvement; en tout cap, elle n’a avance en toot et pour tout que de 1 /16 de tallari. Le j an de cette semaine a paru incompre hensible a plus d’un; le fait est qu’il est quel- que pen extraordinaire. Sur quoi est-il base Il est incontestable que la position a la hausse est entre les mains de la spéculation, plutôt la petite, et si la qualité de quelques detentuers de contrats au Cairo est a prendre en conside ration comme puissance de moyens, il n’en est pas moins vrai que cela ne soffit pas pour modifier la situation do l’article suivant leurs desirs. A cote du decouvert qui certainement existe, mais qui n’a pas l’air de se laisser effrayer encore, il y a la mirchandise effective qui represente la plas grande partie des con- trata en circulation, et ce n’est ni le Caire, qui est surcharge, ni les acheteurs de l’interieur ni nos petits haussiers de la place qui pourront en prendre livraison. En outre, n’oublions pas que parmi nos haussiers il y a aussi de gros bonnets, et ceux-la ont plus d’une corde a leur arc. Par consequent, et pour resumer l’opinion de la majorité, sans un appui efficace du dehors il n’y a pas de reussito assurde poor tonte manoeuvre intempestive on exagérée, et si, par ci, par la, un certain découvert devra se décide? a se racheter, cela ne vent pas dire, dans les conditions que nous venons d’exposer, que le succes couronnera les efforts des manipulateurs a la hausse, surtout si, pour faire monter lea prix, ils sont obliges d’acheter dans le niveau actuel, en gatant leur moyenne deja passable- ment élevée. On dit aussi quo beancoup d’agences sont en train d’acheter de l’Egyptien et de vendre de i’Americain., Si le fait est vrai, et qu’au fond il s’agaisse d’arbitrages anciens qu’on est en train de défaire, cela diminuerait los positions ft la baisse qui existent sur place.; mais si par contre les operateurs du moment croientau- jourd’hui faire une affaire saine en s’engageant sur l’Egyptien et sur l’Americain dans les con- didoes actuelles, ils courent grandement le risque, comme resultat final, de ne trouver que des desillusions, au lieu de ces benefices miro- bolants (indistinguishable) en general les calculs theo- riques sur le papier. Parmi les Arguments des haussiers on fait valoir la bonne marche de l’Egyptien et la
difficulté qui commence pour le choix de
la qualite. Mais si le premier point est vrai, et il l’est pourquoi done montrer de la précipitation et risquer; d'entraver la con- sommation? Ne serait-il pas plus prudent et peut être plus sur de patienter pour attendre qua l’importance de la consommation meme produise soh effet? 'Et pour ce qui est de la soi-disant pénurie du choix, la chose n’est vraie qu’en partie, car jusqu’ici seuls les cotons fins, qui n’ont rien a faire avec les contrats, sont ceux qui semblent ne pas être assez abondants. La demande de la filature continue a être bonne et il est incontestable que la situation du Janvier a beaucoup aide l’exportateur dans ses nouvelles operations ; aussi c’est a cette Cause, c’est a-dire aux achats du Commerce en cette échéance, que l’on doit attribuer la dimi- nution de l’ecart entre le Janvier et le Mars et la peu d’importance des filières ce mois qui, pour la dernière émission, n’ont été une de Cantars 6,000. En livrable sur la prochaine recolte on pre- tend qu’il y a eu de nouveau des affaires, mais on ne signale, en fait, rien de saillant. Le marche disponible a eu une allure plus régulière que par le passe et les transac- tions, somme toute, out été assez satisfaisantes; mais, poor ce qui est des prix,il n’y a aucun changement ft enregistrer, sauf sur les Joan- novich qui ont beneficie de 1/4 de tallari de hausse, non pour cause de rareté, mais a la suite de la demande qui porte depuis q’uelque temps sur les qualités fines. Les exportations ont; dépasse les previsions et le gros total de l’année dernière, ce qui fait que nous avons du meme coup une compensa- tion an deficit de la semaine précédente, lequel, du reste, no provenait que d’un simple, retard dans le règlement des droits sur certains em- barquements, et qui avait empêché la Douane de les donner en note en temps voulu. Pour la semaine prochaine on prédit une augmentation sur l’annee dernière. Seulement, n’oublions pas qu’en 1905 la semaine n’a été que de Balles 21.00Q. Liverpool a ete un peu plus propice a nos cotons comme chiffre de ventes, mais sons le rapport des prix, les choses sont restées an meme point. Il y a eu aussi de l’activitie sur les Ameri- cains, mais, comme cours, il y a en necessaire- ment de la baisse. Manchester va bien et c’est cette circons- tance qui fait dire qu’il ne faut pas s’attendre a une trop forte baisse sur les Americains. Dans tous les cas, beaucoup de monde conseille d’acheter des que nous serons tombes vers les 11 cents, ce qui confirmerait ce que nous avons dit precedemment qu’arrives a un cer- tain point la reprise serait immanquable, la baisse devant finir forcément par modifier, les choses.
Graines de coton La demande pour le disponible n’a cesse d’etre bonne et la semaine a fini en hausse sur le cours do P.T. 61 1 /2.—Les besoins des exportateurs seront considérables poor tout le reste d mois et par conseqnent, si une le reste du mois survenir ce n’est pas de ce cote qu’elle est a craindre. Les embarque ments ont atteint lea previsions ; quant aux engagements futurs, comme dit ci-haut, ils sont sans precedents comme importance pour janvier et ft en juger par lea affrètements connus, ils constitueront un record. En contrata; il y a eu de nonveau de l’activite et c’est toujours par le fait de la speculation. En tous cas, leprix est a 66 1/2 pour l’Avril et la tendance reste ferme. Hull a suivi comme prix et des affaires assez nombreuses ont eu lieu ft £ 6. 5/- La demande, pourtant, semble avoir diminue un peu a la suite de la hausse. Toutefois, avec les besoins existants a cause de la situation de la graine de lin, elle promet de reprendre.

“Investments” introduces, in an entirely original manner, new and important methods for the employment of and the means of obtaining capital. Among the
SPECIALLY CONTRIBUTED ARTICLES
are “Stock Markets and How to Profit by Them”; “Theory of Successful Speculation”; “How to start an Account” ; “The Advantages of ‘Call Options’”; “Contangoing Mining and Industrial Securities” ; “How to Invest in Mines”; “American Rails, with Points for Operators in Yankees”; “The Purchase of Investment Securities by Instalments” ; “General Principles for Investors” ; “Rules for Investors in Mines”; “General Principles for Speculators”; “Stock Exchange Terms,” being a glossary for Market Operators; “Stock Exchange Parlance”; “Insurance, as a Means of Making, Raising, and Saving Money,” and “Colonial Building Land: Its Great Possibilities.”

Circulaire H. de Vries et Boutigny BULLETIN DU LA BOURSE NOTES ET CRITIQUES Caire, 12 janvier. Londres nous a transmis des cours invariés sur le Consolidé anglais, ainsi qne sur les va- leurs égyptiennes. L’Agricultural Bank est, 's sole, renseignée en hausse de J à 9 §. À Paris, ’ l’action Crédit Foncier a gagné 1 franc à 802. Par contre, la Banque d’Athènes a perdu 2 francs à 132. Ce matin, notre marché des valeur# a été encore moins animé. La National Bank et l’Agricole sont restées pins on moins à leurs prix d'hier. La Cassa di Sconto a fléchi jusqu’à 205 pour clôturer à 208. La Banque d’Athènes q été cotée à 133 131. Le Comptoir Financier s’est maintenu entre 4 5/8 et 4 11/16 L’action Crédit Foncier a ouvert à 804 pour clôturer à 8U2 803. L’obligation à lots-1886 revient 332; la nouvelle émission reste à 274. L’Immobilière a avancé à 360.—La part de fondateur Land Allotment a fléchi a 95. L’action Ciments a reculé de 2 francs à 68 ; la part de fondateur a, par contre, avancé à 18. Rien de très particulier à signaler dans le groupe des Hôtels et dans le compartiment des petites valeurs. L’assemblée générale ordinaire de l’Egyptian Delta Light Railways aura lien à Londres le 30 Janvier courant. Le conseil d’administration propose le paie- ment d’un dividende complémentaire de 2 % sur les actions, ce qui, avec le dividende pro- visoire distribué en juin dernier, fera 4 %'pour l’année. On sait que la Cassa di Sconto e di Rispar- mio porte son capital de 5 a 10 millions de franœ moyennant l’émission de 50,000 notions nouvelles de la valeur nominale de 100 francs chacune. Comme nous l’avons déjà dit, 30,000 de ces actions ont été prises ferme, à 135 francs, par un groupe étranger représenté par l’Union Bank de Vienne. Les antres 20,000 actions sont offertes aux actionnaires actuels, an prix de 130 francs, & raison de 2 actions nouvelles pour chaque 5 ac- tions des émissions précédentes. La souscription à ces 20,000 actions sera ouverte, aux guichets la Cassa à Alexandrie et an Caire, le lundi 29 du courant pour être close le lundi suivant 5 février. Les cours da coton sont arrivés en légère baisse d’Amérique, le Mai a perdu 5 et l'Oc- tobre 2 points. Par contre, le disponible a haus- sé de 8 points à 11. 80. Les arrivages ont été de 22.000 balles contre 25,000. Le marché de Liverpool est également en petite réaction. loi, le Mars a ouvert, ce matin, à 15 § pour clôturer à 15 27/32. MM. H. de Vries et Boutigny, agents de change, se chargent de l’exécution de fous ordres de Bourse (valeurs et marchandises) sur les marchés de Londres, Paris, Bruxelles, An- vers, Liverpool et New-York. La Circulaire quotidienne de la maison est envoyée sut demande.

Bulletin De la Bourse (Àujourd" hui à midi et demie) Le marché a été cealm ce matin, mais relati- vement ferme. L’Urbaine a absorbé presque toute l’attention de la spéculation : les bruits de nouvelle émis- sion prenant de là consistance, elle a haussé d'un trait de 5 3/16 à 5 5/16. En hausse également la Filature, la Sait & soda, les Upper Egypt Hotels et la Cassa di scento. Par contre, le Crédit Foncier, l’Agricole nouvelle, les Markets, l’Anglo American Nile et la Delta Light réactionpent légèrement.

OUR LONDON LETTER. (From our Correspondent.) London. January 6. Unless there is a very speedy change in the present arrangements tor the approaching contest, the position of the Unionists at the opening of the struggle will not be so favour able as it ought to be. No one can help noticing that there has been a very marked revival of the courage and confidence of the party during the Let two or three weeks, bat I am sorry to see that this has1 not been followed by a "’corresponding determination to assault every stronghold of the enemy, no matter ht.w impregnable it may seem. Ex- cluding Ireland, which, for these purposes, hardly counts for either party, there are no fewer than twenty-nine Parliamentary Divi- sions in which there is no Unionist candidate at all, and four two-member constituencies in which there is 'holy one. For.a party which could reckon on a majority of seventy over the regular Opposition and the Nation- alists together to leave thirty three seats uncontested seems to me to be palpably wrong. Some of the Welsh seats fir which no Unionist candidates have as yet come forward might. I believe, be attacked with a fair prospect of success, while the abandonment to the Radicals of Shipley, where Sir Fortescue Flannery won so brilliant a victory, cannot be justified on any grounds whatever. Our opponents are making no such mistake. With the exception of the University seats, which are in a category of their own, there are only four constituencies in Great Britain for which Radical-candidates are not forthcoming, if we exclude the Speaker’s seat at Penrith, and it is more than likely that' even these- vacancies will be filled before the I Dissolution. There ought not to be a seat in Great Britain without a Unionist, candidate, I and that there should be so many in that condition now is a very grave indictment of the methods of the local organisations. Statements that this is going to be about the mo3t bitterly fought election on record are strikingly confirmed by the news that one candidate; a Liberal, has gone so far as to impress the gramophone into his service, on the pretext that his constituents are too widely scattered for him to address them personally. And this from a member of the party whitch waxes forensically furious over the alleged cruelties practised on or by (it does not much matter which) "Chinese coolies, which has not hesitated to raise mutterings about the alleged use of dum-dum bullets in oar wars. It is high time, surely, that there was a Geueva Convention to regulate electioneering as well as other campaigns. Yet, natural indignation almost gives place to compassion for one who thus rushes- on his own destruction For, to the acute suffer- ings of the docie elector speciously induced to suffer auricular torture. there will be added the pangs cf enforced self-suppression inflicted upon the would-be hekler. the frenzy of the compulsority ovoise egg-laden marks man. Truly we believe the rash innovation carries its own punishment in its train. With all i s faults our Parliament compares favourably with those of all other countries— Oven of our colonies. Etiquette "down under” tend§, of course, to become lax and the proceedings of the New Zealand House -of Representatives have been invariably stopped to announce the results (of the "All Blacks” matches in England. We hear now of obstruc- tion being carried to such perfection in the commonwealth parliament, that members of the stonewalling type have been bringing bedding into the Chamber, and openly sleeping on it. The action appears to be partly in- tended as a theatrical move to discourage the Government, as the Acting 'Speaker has titled that '"Members must not make their preparations for rest in an offensive manner.” It reminds us of the immortal question, "Did you bite your thumb at me, sir?” A useful summary of Germany’s shipbuilding record in 1905, given by the “Times” to-day, shows that it the year was " rather a quiet one. ” Two battle ships of 13,200 tons, two armoured cruisers of 9,500 and three small cruisers were completed ; and during that period our own activity compares very favourably with that of Germany alone. We completed seventeen vessels as against seven, with a total displace- ment of 150,200. tons as against 55,000. But certainly this is no more than the proportion that should be maintained in comparison with Germany alone, and the full list of German warships of the larger kind completed, constructed, and projected ’in 1905 is worth studying, Altogether there are ten battleships. four armoured cruisers, and eleven protected cruisers- a list which is not alarming in itself,
but which sufficiently shows that Germany is not slackening in a process that continues to cally tor the compliment of imitation and bettering. Admiral Rozhdestvensky seems to belong quite to ancient history now, and it is patheti- cally appropriate to hear that he is likely to be the next Russian Naval Minister—in charge of a navy of equally antiquarian interest. But, even for a voice from Davy ’Jones’s Locker, the gallant Admiral’s latest statement is so Ardently remarkable. Answering ex-Captain Klado on points as to the position of the Russian ships at the beginning of the disastrous battle, he winds np by calmly remarking that, if Togo had not routed him, the British Squadron, which was lying in wait for the purpose at Wei-hai-wei, would have received the order to annihilate the Russians. From Rozhdestvensky himself this is not surprising; his eyes, as the Dogger Bank proved, are patent double-million magnifying 'microscopes of a peculiar kind. Bat i£is astounding that the present Russian Naval Minister should have passed this letter for publication, and no less astounding is the explanation given by' Count Witte to hi9 friend the correspondent of the "Daily Telegraph.” The Naval Minister, he says, simply studied the technical parts of the letter, and "did not notice” the last few lines. That is how they do things in Russia, even under the enlightened Wute regime.
The statement, with some degree of author- ity, has been made that Mr. Winston Churchill has received a sum cf £8.000 down for the "Life” of his father, and, alter the profits of publication have yielded £12.000 to the pub- lishers, he is to have half of any farther gains that may accrue. The amount, even in the present age of high prices, is satisfactory. It compares well with the £200 each which Lord Macaulay received for his essays, and the £20,000, paid' by a single cheque, for his famous “history .” Mr. Gladstone, knowing the value of money, charged £200 for a review article, provided the subject was after his own heart, but he refused the tempting offer of 4s. a word for a contribution to the first number of the “Cosmopolitan Magazine.”
Mr. Gladstone’s yearly income from his pen was £3.000. Mr. Kipling is the most highly paid author of to day, even among writers of fiction. He has had no compunction in falling under "the damna-ion of the cheque book,” and a sun of £2,200 was his reward for "The Seven Seas.” The story goes that a smart American wrote to him thus "Hearing that you are retailing literature at a dollar a word, I enclose one dollar for a sample.” Mr. Kipling is said to have kept the dollar and sent back the single word "Thanks.”
There is something piquant about a society "mainly devoted to the encouragement of Intelligent Conversation amongst Journalists, Bookmerf, Critics, Artists, and others.” The "New Bohemians” is its title, and "University men,” the advertisement announces, with en- gaging candour, “are not necessarily disquali- fied. Acquaintanceship with Omar, Rabelais Pepys, Lamb, Stevenson, and Whistler will be regarded aa an asset,' but literary heresies are not considered unorthodox.” This is good news for. the literary heretic who is not the devotee of all members of the sextet in question. One may become a New Bohemian, for example, though disinclined "to laugh with Rabelais in his easy chair.”
It is with varied emotions that.I receive the latest telephonic news. We are warned (that will seem to many the right word) that in the course of the next few years communication by telephone may be established between Loudon and New York.The present obstacle lies in the difficulty of reducing the size of the necessary inductance coils sufficiently to permit of their being included in an ocean cable But there seem to be strong hopes of overcoming the difficulty and connecting New York successfully with London. Perhaps by that time the tele- phone will have become a blessing without any disguise. But the disguise is at present so nearly perfect that we cannot help a shudder at the thought of ringing up New York., "Buzz, buzz buzz—are you there? are you in there?—mumble, mumble, mumble—no. my dear, two three-far- things—a block of Eries—I want 643 Central— hullo—are you there?—D—arius!” is bad enough when a poor wretch is only trying to get through, to a Metropolitan subscriber. What will it be when the unconnected numbers vainly striving to.reach each- other are divided by the Atlantic? Distance may lend enchant ment or it may not. Who lives will hear. And the prospect is commercially attractive and important, if not personally alluring; The streets of London are perhaps never more interesting than at the present time,
when all the big drapers’ shops in the West- end are holding their animal sales. One of the most remarkable things about the January (indistinguishable) manner in which a woman will hunt for bargains for hours withont showing, the slightest sign of fatigue, while a mere man would have been tired cut in a quarter of the time. Whether the bargains obtained are really so good as an made out is a moot -point, never the less the shopkeepers seems to know what is wanted, and profit accordingly. The people, however, who deserve most pity are the unfortunate assistants, who are kept stand- ing all-day long, with hardly a moment in which to get any food, and without the excite- ment of the shoppers-to bear them up.
There is a new profession for women. Enter- ing a crawled diaper’s shop on a sale day, the woman of ‘open mind ' flatters from counter to counter examining every dress length, deter- mined, to come to no decision until she has scrutinised every single bargain with a price culminating in the three mystic and fascinatiug farthings. In former days such a one, by rule and tradition, emerged, if conscientious, the purchaser of a yard of tape or a packet of pins; otherwise, quite conceivably; empty- handed. All that is over now. Hardly has the purchaser reached her second or third dilemma when there floats in a lady, of the last cry of chic, who manifests so distinct-and pressing a predilection for the goods under consideration that ll.e dubious one, under the spur of rivalry, at once concludes the bargain. Our thanks—need it be said?—are once more due to America, which has evolved the idea of so great a public and private benefits The Decider, as she is called, will be particularly valuable just now, but her general utility should be perennial.
On that third page of the “Daily Mail” which always includes something grateful and comfort- ing, particulars appeared recently of a haven that is about to be opened in Bond-street. It is for that large section of mankind which prefers to have itself rather than submit to the operations, caresses, and conversation Of the barber, but at the same time does not know how to keep its razors in order. Any number of us are thus afflicted. Either we have not the true artist’s subtle, hand with the strop, or we do not grasp the natural history of the razor and bow it must be humored and rested. It is really-like the Martini in Mr. Kipling’s ballad, not to be called a cross-eyed old some- thing, but ‘human as you are ; you treat her as'sich !” At the Bond-street institution the razors will be coaxed and kept fit., and patrons merely have to call and use them—incidentally without having to wait their tarn until someone* else is done with. No doubt individual privacy will be secured; there are some people who could no more shave themselves under the critical eye of a professional barber than others can play billiards in the presence of a super- cilious marker. Further, beginners are to be taught the art and science of self shaving by competent instructors - with a surgeon, per- haps, in attendance. It will be as delightful as learning the banjo or dancing.

THROUGH MOSLEM EYES. Io the course of a profoundly interesting article ou "Christianity from the Islamic Stand- point,” . in the current "Hibbert Journal,” Ameer Ali, lately a judge in’ Bengal, says that both LlA n and Christianity have identi- cal aims and ideals ; both agres in their gene- ral principles. Even in matters of dogma the agreement is often astonishing. .... In view of the denunciations of the Nazirene Prophet against the rich, and the promise of the Kingdom of Heaven to tie poor and the humble, the Moslem fails t.o understand the, feverish pursuit of wealth in the Western world, the devotion to luxury, the unregulated dispensing of charity, the callouuness to distress and Buffering, the con- tempt fir the virtues which Jesus inculcated -patience, meekness, and humility of spirit; or why ;he system which styled its founder “the Prince of Peace” should got be able to suppress war and rapine among his followers. . . ,How is it, asks the Moslem, that modem Christianity, with its philosophic ideals, can- not root out the evil of racial exclusiveness ? Islam makes charity a part of the obligatory rules. In the Christian system this is left to individual sentiment. Here and there it finds practical expression in a Barnardo or a Booth; but unless the suffering is forcibly visible or offensive to the aesthetic sense, much that might relieve poignant distress at home is diverted to the making of distant and doubtful converts. ... Moslems do not recognise that modern Christianity, overladen with Greek philosophy and Pauline mysticism, represents the religion Jesus in fact taught. They consider that Islam represents true Christianity. They do not think that, Jesus, who prayed in the wilder- ness and on the' hillside, in the huts of the peasants, in the humble abodes of the fisher- men, furnished any warrant for the gorgeons- ness of modern Christian worship, with all the accessories which beguile the mind, mystify the intellect, and thus divert the human heart from the worship of the great God towards a symbol and a type.
